First, hyperspectral images of corn seeds subjected to five different freezing temperatures were acquired. The average spectra were then extracted from the region of embryo hyperspectral images over a specific wavelength range. Four models (K nearest neighbors, support vector machine, extreme learning machine, and DCNN) were developed for both five-category and four-category classifications of freeze-damaged corn seeds. Evaluation indexes such as accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and precision were calculated to compare the performance of the models. The results showed that the DCNN model had the most satisfactory results in terms of accuracy rates for both five-category and four-category classifications. Additionally, a visual classification map was generated based on the results of the DCNN model. Overall, the study demonstrated that hyperspectral imaging combined with DCNN can provide a quick and inexpensive method to detect freezing damage in corn seeds.
